Subsubsection Text: As part of our quarterly revaluation process, w e have identified negative adjustments due to low ered collection expectations on specific investment portfolios that negatively impacted our profit and loss account as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The book value of our Intesa joint venture w as reduced by SEK 2,460 million, and as a direct consequence, client relationships reduced by SEK 393 million and a fair value loss on derivative amounted to SEK 95 million. In the fourth quarter of 2022, w e w ill further reduce the book value of the Intesa JV recognized in our financial statements by approximately SEK 3.1 billion and recognize an impairment loss on related customer relationships of approximately SEK 0.2 billion. This is to reflect the updated valuation of our 62.5% exposure in Intesa JV implied by the CarVal-Kistefos Transaction in November 2022. We w ill also low er ERC associated w ith the Intesa JV by approximately SEK 5.4 billion. Concurrently w ith the CarValKistefos Transaction, w e settled the CarVal Derivative, resulting in a cash loss of approximately SEK 1.1 billion. See “Summary–Recent Developments–CarVal-Kistefos Transaction” and "Risk Factors – _Risks related to our _industry and business – The value of our existing portfolios may deteriorate or we may not be able to collect sufficient amounts on our portfolios to take advantage of opportunities for portfolio purchases as they arise in the market" for more information._ The impairments and fair value loss are non-cash items and w ill not impact our key performance and leverage metrics as the former is adjusted as an item affecting comparability and the latter is recognized below the EBIT line and removed as a normalization adjustment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: IFRIC Interpretation: Attributing Benefit to Periods of Service (April 2021)
Subsubsection Text: In April 2021, IFRIC issued an interpretation on IAS 19 Employee Benefits that requires an entity to attribute benefits to periods of service. The period of service starts w hen an entity has an obligation tow ards the employee until the service period w hen additional service does not impact timing or amount of the final benefit. The Group prospectively adopted this interpretation w ith effect from January 1, 2021. This impacted the Group's Greek subsidiary, Intrum Hellas AEDADP, w here employees are entitled to a lump sum payment based on their final salary (benefit formula), provided these employees w ere in continuous employment for 16 years. Previously, the benefit w as attributable to the full service period and the pension obligation covered all employees. As a result of the interpretation, the pension obligation and service costs are now only computed for employees w ho are at least 46 years old and w ill complete 16 years of continuous service. This has resulted in a reduction in pension obligation from SEK 110 million to SEK 41 million and reduction in service costs of SEK 38 million. Consequently, the retained earnings increased by SEK 38 million and other comprehensive income increased by SEK 30 million. 70 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Other Restatements and Presentational Changes
Subsubsection Text: The follow ing restatements and presentational changes have been made to the comparative figures for the year ended December 31, 2020 included in the 2021 Financial Statements: - "Reduction of interest paid" for the year ended December 31, 2020 included in the 2020 Financial Statements, impacting cash flow s from operating activities in the statement of cash flow s, has been restated in the 2021 Financial Statements as "Borrowing and repayments of loans," impacting cash flow s from investing activities in the statement of cash flow s. This change resulted in a decrease in "cash flow from operating activities" in an amount of SEK 210 million and a corresponding increase in "cash flow from financing activities" of SEK 210 million, in each case for the year ended December 31, 2020, as reflected in the 2021 Financial Statements. - In the 2021 Financial Statements, the amortization method for the client servicing assets was changed from a straight-line method to a diminishing balance method. The impact of this change, as reflected in the 2021 Financial Statements and the Interim Statements, w as SEK 15 million. We believe that the diminishing balance method more accurately depicts the underlying cashflow s. - Certain balance sheet line items for the year ended December 31, 2020 included in the 2020 Financial Statements, including "capitalised expenditure for IT development and other intangibles," "other _intangible fixed assets," "total intangible fixed assets," "total fixed assets," "total assets," "Retained earnings including net earnings for the year," "total shareholders' equity attributable to parent company's shareholders," "shareholders' equity attributable to non-controlling interests," "total shareholders' equity," "other long-term liabilities," "total long-term liabilities" and "total shareholders' equity and liabilities" have been restated in the 2021 Financial Statements to more accurately reflect_ several factors including: intangible assets w rite-offs, a restatement of Aktua's non-controlling interest, Aktua's put/call liability and Solvia's put/call liability (in December 2022, w e settled Solvia’s put option as part of the December 2022 Solvia Acquisition, See “ _Summary—Recent _Developments— Acquisition of the Remaining 20% Stake in Solvia”). These restatements resulted in_ (i) net increases in "total intangible fixed assets," "total fixed assets" and "total assets" of SEK 67 million, (ii) a decrease in "retained earnings including net earnings for the year" of SEK 440 million, (iii) a decrease in "total shareholders' equity attributable to parent company's shareholders" of SEK 442 million, (iv) a decrease in "total shareholders' equity attributable to non-controlling interests" of SEK 70 million, (v) a decrease in "total shareholders' equity" of SEK 372 million, (vi) increases in "other long term liabilities" and "total long term liabilities" of SEK 439 million and (vii) a net increase in "total shareholders' equity and liabilities" of SEK 67 million, in each case as of December 31, 2020 and as reflected in the 2021 Financial Statements. - The presentation of certain income statement line items for the year ended December 31, 2020 included in the 2020 Financial Statements has been modified in the 2021 Financial Statements as follow s: (i) "provisions for credit losses on accounts receivable" of negative SEK 69 million in the 2020 Financial Statements is presented under "sales, marketing and administrative expenses," resulting in a corresponding decrease of SEK 69 million thereto, in the 2021 Financial Statements; (ii) "share of _the profit or loss on joint ventures accounted for using the equity method" of negative SEK 734 million_ in the 2020 Financial Statements is presented under "participation in associated companies," resulting in a corresponding decrease of SEK 734 million thereto, in the 2021 Financial Statements; and (iii) the line item "net exchange gains/losses" of SEK 16 million has been added in the 2021 Financial Statements, resulting in a corresponding decrease of SEK 16 million to "financial income" in the 2021 Financial Statements. - With effect from January 1, 2022, Portfolio Investment amortization w ill be reclassified from operating cashflow s to investing cashflow s as this is technically, and based on industry practice, a more helpful presentation. This change is expected to be implemented in the audited consolidated financial statements of the Issuer 2022. This change w ill not change our EBIT, EBITDA, Cash EBITDA, or EBITDA Margin as described under " –Non-IFRS Measures" below or our key operating metrics set forth under " –Key Operating Metrics" below, w hich are in line w ith the industry practice.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Recognition of purchased portfolios, revenue recognition, accounting treatment of joint ventures, estimation of cash flow forecasts and revaluation of purchased portfolios
Subsubsection Text: The follow ing sections describe how the IFRS accounting under the amortized cost methodology recognizes the portfolio investments book value in our consolidated statement of financial position and the returns generated through debt collections on such portfolios in our consolidated income statement. These IFRS measures are derived from a number of other measures that are not defined in IFRS and w hich involve a higher degree of judgment or complexity, including EIR and ERC, and these are areas w here assumptions and estimates are significant to the Issuer's Audited Financial Statements. 71 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Recognition of portfolio investments
Subsubsection Text: Portfolio investments consist of portfolios of delinquent debt purchased at prices significantly below the nominal receivable. In accordance w ith the rules for loans and receivables under IFRS 9, portfolio investments are recognized at amortized cost according to the effective interest rate model. The current rules for portfolio investments require that w e report these according to an EIR model. In accordance w ith IFRS 9, acquired creditimpaired receivables can be reported at a higher recognized value than cost if our estimates of future cash flows change. Income from portfolio investments is recognized in the income statement as the collected amount less amortization. The collection is often performed by the same personnel w ho handle collections and debt surveillance on behalf of external clients w ithin the Credit Management Services segment and Strategic Markets segment. The cost of collection is debited internally at market price and expensed in the income statement for the Portfolio Investments segment as a cost of services. Reporting follow s the effective interest method, w here the carrying value of each portfolio corresponds to the present value of all projected future cash flow s discounted by an initial EIR determined on the date the portfolio w as acquired, based on the relation betw een purchase price cost and the projected future cash flow s on the acquisition date. Changes in the portfolio investments book value are recognized as amortization for the period and included in the income statement on the revenue line. Compensation received from debt originators due to rejected cases and price adjustments made to purchased portfolios are recorded as an adjustment to the acquisition cost. In connection w ith the purchase of each portfolio of receivables, a projection for a period of 180 months is made of the portfolio's cash flow s. Cash flow s include the loan amount, reminder fees, collection fees and late interest that, based on a probability assessment, are expected to be received from debtors, less forecast collection costs. With this forecast and the purchase price (including transaction costs) as a basis, each portfolio is assigned an initial EIR that is then used to discount cash flow s through the life of the portfolio. Cash flow actual performance is compared against projections and monitored on a monthly basis for all portfolios, although adjustments to projections are typically only made after the first year. Projections are updated based on, among other things, achieved collection results, agreements reached w ith debtors on instalment plans and macroeconomic information. Cash flow projections are made at the portfolio level, since each portfolio of receivables consists of a small number of homogeneous amounts. On the basis of the updated cash flow projections and initial EIR, a new carrying value for the portfolio is calculated in the closing accounts. The effects of changes in cash flow forecasts are referred to as revaluations and treated symmetrically, _i.e., both increases and decreases in forecast flow s affect a given portfolio's portfolio investments book value and,_ as a result, earnings. Portfolios may be recognized at higher than cost if future cash flow forecasts change. Although selling portfolios of portfolio investments is not a part of our business model, w hen such sales do occur as an exception, the resulting sales price received for the portfolio is reported in the same w ay as if it had been collected from the debtors. The entire remaining carrying values of the portfolios are then recognized as amortization. From time to time, w e also purchase portfolios on a forw ard flow basis. In a forw ard flow agreement, we agree to buy claims from a client on an ongoing basis at a pre-defined price or price range for a given volume and quality. Claims under forw ard flow agreements can be delivered on w eekly, monthly or quarterly basis and the EIR of these claims is calculated per batch delivered. Each delivery under a forw ard flow agreement is treated as an individual portfolio purchase, using our ow n purchase cost and our ow n EIR calculation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Recognition of revenue from portfolio investments
Subsubsection Text: Revenue on a portfolio investment is calculated as the total of the actual achieved gross collected amounts of the portfolio during each month, less portfolio investment amortization and adjusted for positive or negative portfolio investment revaluations. As a result of this methodology, revenue for a portfolio w ill correspond closely to its carrying value multiplied by the EIR that w ould have been determined if the calculation had been based on gross collections, adjusted for over- or under-performance and for revaluations. The table below sets forth an illustrative example of portfolio revenue recognition and changes in portfolio investments book value according our methodology under IFRS. MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Joint ventures
Subsubsection Text: In accordance w ith IFRS 11 Joint arrangements, w e recognize our participations in joint ventures, in w hich w e and other part-ow ners manage operations jointly in accordance w ith a shareholder agreement, in accordance w ith the equity method from the date on w hich joint control arises and such that w e are entitled to net assets rather than having a direct entitlement to assets and responsibility for liabilities. Joint ventures are recognized at cost and subsequently adjusted for our share of net assets. In our consolidated income statement, our share of joint venture earnings is reported under Participations in associated companies. We do not recognize dividends received from joint ventures in the income statement, but instead reduce the carrying value of the investment. Shared operations are joint arrangements in w hich w e and one or more partners are entitled to all of the financial benefits related to the assets of the operations. Shared operations are reported according to the profit split method under w hich each party to a joint venture reports its share of assets, liabilities, income and expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Estimation of cash flow forecasts from portfolio investments
Subsubsection Text: The estimation of cash flow forecasts (i.e., ERC) is a key uncertainty w ithin our policies on revenue recognition of portfolio investments. We establish estimates of cash flow s that determine the EIR for each purchased portfolio. The estimates are based on our collection history w ith respect to portfolios comprising similar attributes and characteristics, such as date of purchase, debt originator, type of receivable, customer payment histories, customer location and the time since the original charge-off, as w ell as on our experience and the existing schedule of repayment plans on the particular portfolio for w hich w e are determining EIR.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Revaluation of portfolio investments
Subsubsection Text: Prior to the end of each quarterly reporting period, w e evaluate portfolio forecasts to assess w hether there is objective evidence that a portfolio should be subject to revaluation. Indications of positive or negative revaluation primarily include any significant deviation against the currently active forecast for the portfolio, but also take into account an assessment of groups of customers experiencing financial difficulty, default of interest or principal payments, the probability that customers w ill enter into bankruptcy, debt restructuring or other financial 73 ----- reorganization and observable data indicating that there is a measurable decrease in the estimated future cash flow s, such as changes in arrears or economic conditions that correlate w ith defaults. Conversely, there can also be a positive revaluation in the event that a portfolio displays objective evidence of expected cash flow s above the currently active forecast. In practice, a number of portfolios are identified each quarter for potential revaluation. Generally, portfolios w ill be selected for potential revaluation only w here (i) w e have ow ned such portfolio for at least 12 months, (ii) net collections in the past 12 months, or since the latest revaluation w ithin the past 12 months, for such portfolio have deviated more than 10% positively or negatively against the active forecast, and (iii) net collections in the past 12 months for such portfolio have exceeded €100,000. Portfolios that do not fulfill all four of these criteria are not considered for revaluation unless a special request is made by country or regional management. Portfolios w hich fulfill all four criteria are considered as candidates for a potential revaluation and are analyzed by our staff at group and local levels to determine if the deviation in the past indicates a need to revise the forecast for the future. New forecasts may be generated using agreed-upon statistical methods. All changes in active collection forecasts are then signed off and agreed by our revaluation committee. All changes to the forecast lead to a book value adjustment. On a yearly basis all portfolios w ith 10% deviation are review ed and revalued. In 2020 our collection performance w as impacted by the economic dow nturn and closure of certain legal functions in certain of our key markets caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. We have reflected this impact through our book value revaluations processes. In the year ended December 31, 2020, w e w rote dow n our portfolio investment by net SEK 33 million, w hich is 0.1% of our portfolio investment carrying value as of December 31, 2020. In the year ended December 31, 2021. For our secured portfolios, due to closures of courts, ban on enforcements and initial shock to the property market w e w rote dow n our secured portfolio by SEK 168 million representing 8.1% of the total secured book value at the time. An additional SEK 52 million w rite-dow n w as made in the first half of 2021 to further reflect the impact. The revaluations w ere done on a market level to reflect the conditions present in the market at the time of the revaluation. Additionally, as part of our quarterly revaluation process, w e have identified negative adjustments due to low ered collection expectations on specific investment portfolios that negatively impacted our profit and loss account as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The book value of our Intesa joint venture was reduced by SEK 2,460 million, and as a direct consequence, client relationships reduced by SEK 393 million and a fair value loss on derivative amounted to SEK 95 million. In the fourth quarter of 2022, w e w ill further reduce the book value of the Intesa JV recognized in our financial statements by approximately SEK 3.1 billion and recognize an impairment loss on related customer relationships of approximately SEK 0.2 billion. This is to reflect the updated valuation of our 62.5% exposure in Intesa JV implied by the CarVal-Kistefos Transaction in November 2022. We w ill also low er ERC associated w ith the Intesa JV by approximately SEK 5.4 billion. See “Summary–Recent _Developments–CarVal-Kistefos Transaction” for more information._ The impairments and fair value loss are non-cash items and w ill not impact our key performance and leverage metrics as the former is adjusted as an item affecting comparability and the latter is recognized below the EBIT line and removed as a normalization adjustment. The negative adjustments to our Italian joint ventures w ill reduce the associated ERC from 2025 onw ards by SEK 1.6 billion to ERC of SEK 5.9 billion. This is a reduction of approximately 2% relative to our total ERC forecast of SEK 82 billion as of the second quarter of 2022. See "Risk Factors – Risks related to our industry and business –The value of our existing portfolios may _deteriorate or we may not be able to collect sufficient amounts on our portfolios to take advantage of opportunities for portfolio purchases as they arise in the market."_

Subsubsection Title: Portfolio investments
Subsubsection Text: Portfolio investments consist primarily of portfolios of loans and other overdue receivables purchased at prices significantly below the nominal total collectible value on the portfolios and w hich are recognized at amortized cost using the effective interest method. The carrying value of each portfolio corresponds to the present value of estimated future cash flow s discounted by an EIR. The initial EIR is based on the relation betw een purchase cost and the projected future cash flow s on the date of purchase. See "—Significant factors affecting our results of _operations—Recognition of portfolio investments, revenue recognition, estimation of cash flow forecasts and revaluation of portfolio investments."_

Subsubsection Title: Total revenue
Subsubsection Text: Consolidated total revenue includes external CMS income (variable collection commissions, fixed collection fees, debtor fees, guarantee commissions, subscription income, etc.), income from portfolio investments in accordance w ith the effective interest method w here the carrying value of each portfolio corresponds to the present value of all projected future cash flow s discounted by an initial EIR determined on the date the portfolio w as acquired and positive revaluations of portfolio investments less negative revaluations of portfolio inves tments.

Subsubsection Title: Cost of sales
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales are cost of services, including (i) production expenses including all costs directly incurred in order to establish the reported total revenues, (ii) sales expense associated w ith existing clients including costs associated w ith the maintenance of existing clients and adding value to the relationship, such as complaints management and (iii) related IT expenses including the running and maintenance costs for IT infrastructure. Cost of sales also include costs for personnel, postage, purchase of external information, legal and bailiff costs, bank charges for client funds bank accounts, apportioned rent and office costs as w ell as depreciation on related fixed assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of key consolidated income statement line items
Subsubsection Title: Sales, marketing and administrative expenses
Subsubsection Text: Sales, marketing and administrative expenses include (i) sales expense associated w ith new clients including costs associated w ith selling activities, preparation of customer contracts, w riting of order specifications, sales promotion, administration of order filling and billing, (ii) marketing expenses including advertising, promotion, marketing staff costs, market analyses, planning of market strategy, sponsoring and (iii) invoicing and administrative expenses including group, regional and local level costs for finance and human resource departments as w ell as board of directors and group and local management. Sales, marketing and administrative expenses also include staff costs, consultancies, audit fees, costs for IT support, apportioned rent and office costs, depreciation on related fixed assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of key consolidated income statement line items
Subsubsection Title: Participations in associated companies
Subsubsection Text: Refers to our share of profit or loss in joint ventures recognized in accordance w ith IAS 28. For further information, see "—Recognition of purchased portfolios, revenue recognition, accounting treatment of joint _ventures, estimation of cash flow forecasts and revaluation_ _of purchased portfolios—Joint ventures" and Notes 1,_ 4 and 14 in the 2021 Audited Financial Statements included elsew here in this Offering Memorandum. We are currently party to the follow ing joint venture arrangements. _Ithaca Investment DAC (Intesa JV)_ In April 2018, w e entered into a partnership agreement w ith Intesa pertaining to the establishment of a shared Italian collection business and the securitization of non-performing loans originated by Intesa. In the context of the Intesa Partnership: - w e acquired a majority 51% holding in a Italian collection business, Intrum Italy, to w hich Intesa contributed its service platform for overdue receivables, and Intrum contributed all of its Italian operations at the time (other than Cross Factor SpA and the holding company Lindorff Italy Srl). Intesa retains a 49% holding in Intrum Italy. In connection w ith this, Intrum Italy also entered into a 10-year exclusive servicing agreement w ith Intesa for the vast majority of Intesa's new NPL inflow during this 78 ----- period. Intesa retains a 49% holding in Intrum Italy, and w e therefore consolidate Intrum Italy's results of operations. At the same time Intrum together w ith CarVal Investors acquired 51% of a portfolio of overdue receivables from Intesa, w hich is held by Penelope, an Italian special purpose vehicle, as described below . - through a new joint company, Ithaca Investment DAC (the "Intesa JV"), w e ow n profit participating notes corresponding to 62.5% of the capital of the Intesa JV. The Intesa JV is subject, by agreement, to controlling influence shared by Intrum and our co-investor (w hich, follow ing the CarVal-Kistefos Transaction, is Kistefos) and w e therefore report our interest in the jointly ow ned platform as a participation in a joint venture. The Intesa JV has invested in junior notes and mezzanine loans issued by Penelope. Penelope has invested in overdue receivables acquired from Intesa. Penelope also controls the property company, Savoy Reoco S.R.L., w hich assumes control of seized collateral in the form of properties. On December 29, 2021, Penelope w as restructured and refinanced w ith longer duration senior notes. The senior notes are intended to be eligible for a state guarantee, Garanzia Cartolarizzazione Sofferenze ("GACS"). As part of the transaction, Intesa JV's holding in the notes increased from 51% to 95%. In addition, Intrum reduced its holdings in the profit participating notes of the Intesa JV from 80% to 62.5% in Intesa JV. This resulted in a loss of SEK 40 million for Intrum. See "—Acquisitions, geographic expansion and divestments ." During the third quarter of 2022, the book value of the Intesa JV recognized in our financial statements w as reduced by SEK 2,460 million. As a direct consequence, client relationships w as reduced by SEK 393 million and a fair value loss on derivative amounted to SEK 95 million. This w as due to low ered collection expectations on specific portfolios invested via joint venture arrangements, principally our Italian joint ventures. In the fourth quarter of 2022, w e w ill further reduce the book value of the Intesa JV recognized in our financial statements by approximately SEK 3.1 billion and recognize an impairment loss on related customer relationships of approximately SEK 0.2 billion. This is to reflect the updated valuation of our 62.5% exposure in Intesa JV implied by the CarVal-Kistefos Transaction in November 2022. We w ill also low er ERC associated w ith the Intesa JV by approximately SEK 5.4 billion. Concurrently w ith the CarVal-Kistefos Transaction, w e settled the CarVal Derivative, resulting in a cash loss of approximately SEK 1.1 billion. See “Summary–Recent Developments–CarVal-Kistefos Transaction” for more information. _Other joint ventures_ We also have a number of smaller joint ventures in Spain, Italy, Greece and the Netherlands w hich are measured in the Group's consolidated financial statements using the equity method and w hich collectively as of December 31, 2021 had a carrying amount of SEK 6,437 million as show n in the table below (w hich excludes any impairments and adjustments from January 1, 2022 onw ards and do not reflect any revaluation follow ing the CarVal-Kistefos Transaction).

Cost of sales includes items affecting comparability that increased to negative SEK 658 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 compared to negative SEK 36 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, primarily due to increased costs associated w ith our ONE Intrum transformation program. Sales, marketing and administrative expenses includes items affecting comparability that increased to negative SEK 205 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 compared to SEK 56 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, primarily due to increase in costs associated w ith our ONE Intrum transformation program. As a percentage of total revenue, sales, marketing and administrative expenses increased from 12% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to 14% for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. _Participations in joint ventures_ Our income from participations in associated companies and joint ventures decreased significantly by SEK 2,422 million, from SEK 169 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to negative SEK 2,253 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, primarily due to our investment in Ithaca w hich was refinanced at the end of 2021. Operating earnings include items affecting comparability of negative SEK 3,428 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 compared to negative SEK 224 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, out of w hich the deviation of negative SEK 3,204 million is related to increase in costs associated w ith our ONE Intrum transformation program and negative adjustments follow ing revaluations of specific investment portfolios. Accordingly, operating earnings excluding items affecting comparability increased by SEK 77 million to SEK 4,736 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 compared to SEK 4,659 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021. _Net financial items_ Our financial items decreased slightly by SEK 33 million, or 2%, from a loss of SEK 1,610 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to a loss of SEK 1,643 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Interest net increased by SEK 100 million, primarily due to an increase in average debt and higher market rates affecting floating debt. This w as offset by a revaluation on put/call liability on minority interest w hich reduced other financial items by approximately SEK 140 million. _Tax expense_ Our tax expense decreased significantly by SEK 218 million, or 32%, from SEK 685 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to SEK 467 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, primarily due to low er earnings after financial items. _Net earnings for the period_ Net earnings decreased by SEK 2,944 million, from SEK 2,141 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to negative SEK 803 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022.

The increase in total revenue from the year ended December 31, 2020 to the year ended December 31, 2021 w as mainly attributable to particularly strong performance in our portfolio investments segment, w hich benefitted from the diversity and breadth of the segment's portfolio, as w ell as our success in selecting and w inning transactions w ith a strong risk-rew ard profile. Strategic markets also w ere a significant contributor to the increase in revenue in light of a broad-based, sharp recovery from the w orst effects of the COVID-19 pandemic w ith a very strong finish to 2021. Subsubsection Text: (1) Group eliminations relate to intragroup revenues, which primarily consists of payment on arm's length terms for work carried out with in our Credit Management Services and Strategic Markets segments with regard to handling and collection on our portfolio investments. Payment is made in the f orm of a commission that is recognized as a cost within the Portfolio Investments segment. _Cost of sales_ Our cost of sales remained largely consistent throughout the period under review increasing by SEK 54 million, or 1%, from SEK 9,501 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, to SEK 9,555 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. Cost of sales include items affecting comparability that increased to negative SEK 299 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, from positive SEK 30 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. _Sales, marketing and administrative expenses_ Our sales, marketing and administrative expenses increased by SEK 202 million, or 10%, from SEK 1,918 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, to SEK 2,051 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 primarily due to increased administrative expenses. Sales, marketing and administrative expenses include items affecting comparability that increased to negative SEK 84 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, from SEK 0 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. _Participation in associated companies_ Our revenue from participation in associated companies increased to SEK 293 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to a loss of SEK 734 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The biggest driver of this increase w as the fact that in the year ended December 31, 2020, there w as a SEK 1,040 million negative impact to participation in associated companies from non-recurring items, adjustments of methods and estimates on the cash flow s and portfolio revaluations. In comparison, in the year ended December 31, 2021, there w as only a SEK 288 million negative impact from revaluations that impacted the participation in associated companies. _EBIT_ Our profitability measured by EBIT increased significantly by SEK 1,780 million, or 38%, from SEK 4,695 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, to SEK 6,475 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase w as primarily due the fact that w hile our total revenue increased by SEK 941 million, or 6% during the period under review, our operating expenses only increased by SEK 187 million, or 2%, during the same period. In the year ended December 31, 2021 there w ere items affecting comparability in the amount of SEK 538 million, and 82 ----- accordingly, operating earnings excluding items affecting comparability increased to SEK 7,014 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 from SEK 5,738 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. _Net financial items_ Our net financial items increased by SEK 112 million, or 5%, from a cost of SEK 2,062 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, to a cost of SEK 2,174 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. Financial cost increased primarily due to increase in financial expenses. The increase in financial expense w as SEK 63 million primarily due to the issuance of new bonds in the second half of 2020 that resulted in an increase of interest expenses. Exchange rate differences had a negative impact of SEK 11 million on net financial items for the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to a gain of SEK 16 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. _Tax expense_ Our tax expense increased significantly by SEK 355 million, or 64%, from SEK 555 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, to SEK 910 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 primarily due to increased earnings. Tax expense as a percentage of earnings before tax w as 21% for the year ended December 31, 2020 and remained unchanged at 21% for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Net earnings for the period_ Our net earnings for the period increased significantly by SEK 1,313 million, or 63%, from SEK 2,078 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, to SEK 3,391 million in the year ended December 31, 2021.

Subsubsection Text: 83 ----- (1) Group eliminations relate to intragroup revenues, which primarily consists of payment on arm's length terms for work carried out with in our Credit Management Services and Strategic Markets segments with regard to handling and collection on our portfolio investments. Payment is made in the f orm of a commission that is recognized as a cost within the Portfolio Investments segment. _Cost of sales_ Our cost of sales decreased slightly by SEK 306 million, or 3%, from SEK 9,807 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to SEK 9,501 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 primarily due to improved efficiency and a strong focus on cost control. _Sales, marketing and administration expenses_ Our sales, marketing and administration expenses decreased significantly by SEK 704 million, or 28%, from SEK 2,553 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to SEK 1,849 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Sales, marketing and administration expenses include items affecting comparability that w ere SEK 0 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to negative SEK 834 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. _Goodwill impairment_ We recognized goodw ill impairment of SEK 2,700 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 relating to our historic segment of Iberian Peninsula and Latin America. There w as no goodw ill impairment for any subsequent period. _Provisions for credit losses on accounts receivable_ Our provisions for credit losses on accounts receivable increased significantly by SEK 25 million, or 57%, from SEK 44 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to SEK 69 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 primarily due to increased risks associated w ith specific customers in Spain, Germany and Italy. _Share of the profit or loss of joint ventures accounted for using the equity method_ Our share of the profit or loss of joint ventures accounted for using the equity method w as a loss of SEK 734 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to a profit of SEK 1,179 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The loss w as primarily due to a loss from adjustments of methods and estimates on the cash flow s as w ell a revaluation of the Italian JV portfolio in 2020. _Operating earnings (EBIT)_ Our operating earnings (EBIT) increased significantly by SEK 2,635 million, or 128%, from SEK 2,060 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to SEK 4,695 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Operating earnings include items affecting comparability of negative SEK 1,043 million in 2020, mainly consisting of items affecting comparability in joint ventures caused by changes in accounting estimates for calculating amortised cost using effective interest rate method. In 2019, operating earnings included items affecting comparability of negative SEK 4,148 million, primarily caused by impairment of goodw ill of SEK 2,700 million, and costs related to an efficiency improvement programme of SEK 656 million. Accordingly, operating earnings excluding items affecting comparability decreased to SEK 5,738 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 from SEK 6,208 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. _Net financial items_ Our net financial items increased by SEK 141 million, or 7%, from negative SEK 1,921 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 to negative SEK 2,062 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. Financial expenses increased primarily due to increased interest costs as a consequence of an increased average debt level over the year and higher coupon payments on new debt. Exchange rate differences had a positive impact of SEK 17 million on net financial items for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to SEK 19 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. _Tax expense_ Our tax expense increased significantly by SEK 131 million, or 31%, from SEK 424 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to SEK 555 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 primarily due to increased earnings. Tax expense as a percentage of earnings before tax decreased to 21% for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to 305% for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to a non-deductible impairment of goodw ill in 2019. 84 ----- _Net earnings for the period_ Our net earnings for the period w as a profit of SEK 2,078 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to a loss of SEK 285 million for the year ended December 31, 2019.

Subsection Title: Results of operations on a segment basis
Subsubsection Text: Prior to January 1, 2020, the Issuer's operating segments w ere comprised of four geographical regions and the Issuer also reported certain results by service offering, w hich w ere divided into tw o service lines: (i) the Credit Management Services service line and (ii) the Portfolio Investments service line. From January 1, 2020, we have operated our business and presented our financial information on the basis of three segments: (i) our Credit Management Services segment; (ii) our Strategic Markets segment; and (iii) our Portfolio Investments segment. Our financial information for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 (including the comparative information for the nine months ended September 30, 2021) and the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020 is presented on the basis of such three segments. As a result of the change in segment reporting as described above, the results of operations on a service line basis for the year ended December 2019 are not directly comparable to the results of operations on a segment basis for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 (including the comparative information for the nine months ended September 30, 2021) and the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020. The financial information previously presented under the service line of Credit Management Services for our results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2019 is now divided and presented in the tw o segments of Credit Management Services and Strategic Markets in our new three segment organization. In this Offering Memorandum, for ease of comparability, w e present the financial information for the year ended December 31 2019 on the basis of our three segment organization. See "Presentation of Financial and Other Information" for more information regarding the change in our operating and reporting segments.

Subsubsection Title: Cash flows
Subsubsection Text: The follow ing table sets forth the principal components of our cash flow s for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2020 and 2019 and the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Historically, our liquidity requirements primarily arose as a result of servicing debt, payment of taxes and funding our purchased portfolios, capital expenditure and w orking capital. Our primary source of liquidity has been borrow ings under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and cash flow from operations. Additional key sources of liquidity include the Backstop Revolving Credit Facility and capital markets transactions. Historically, our collections have generated a stable and predictable cash flow throughout the year in contrast to the debt purchasing activities, w hich vary betw een quarters. Our debt purchasing activities are driven by supply of portfolios in the market, w hich w e do not control, and our w illingness to invest in any particular available assets at the prevailing price. This can lead to volatility in our free cash flow on a quarter by quarter basis. For example, in 2021 our quarterly cash flow used in investing activities varied betw een SEK 1,167 million and SEK 2,680 million and our quarterly cash flow from operating activities betw een SEK 1,798 million and SEK 3,206 million. Our cash flow generated from operating activities depends on our future operating performance w hich to an extent is dependent on the general economic environment, market competition and the regulatory environment in jurisdictions in w hich w e operate. See "Risk Factors."

Cash flow generated from operating activities_ Our cash flow from operating activities decreased by SEK 1,444 million, or 21%, from an inflow of SEK 6,835 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to an inflow of SEK 5,391 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The decrease w as primarily due to changes in our w orking capital w hich generated cash inflow s in 2021 versus cash outflow s in 2022 due to certain non-recurring items in the Strategic Markets. Our cash flow from operating activities increased by SEK 1,536 million, or 18%, from an inflow of SEK 8,506 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, to an inflow of SEK 10,042 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase is attributable to better operating performance in 2021 as compared to 2020 mainly due to a continuous improvement program in the management of w orking capital w hich generated changes in w orking capital of SEK 1,172 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 as compared to SEK 430 million in the same period of 2020. Our cash flow from operating activities increased by SEK 2,324 million, or 36%, from an inflow of SEK 6,392 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, to an inflow of SEK 8,716 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase is attributable to better operating performance in 2020 as compared to 2019 mainly due to improved management of w orking capital w hich generated positive changes in w orking capital of SEK 430 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to a negative change in w orking capital of SEK 324 million absorbed in the year ended December 31, 2019. _Cash flow from/(used in) investing activities_ Our cash flow used in investing activities decreased by SEK 47 million, or 1%, from SEK 5,329 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to SEK 5,282 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The decrease w as primarily due to higher investments in portfolio receivables in the first nine months of 2022 of SEK 5,307 million compared to SEK 4,705 million of those made during the same period in 2021, partially offset by other investing activities w hich generated cash inflow s in 2022 versus cash outflow s in 2021 due to our investment in certain JVs in Greece. Our cash flow used in investing activities increased significantly by SEK 2,566 million, or 47%, from an outflow of SEK 5,443 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, to an outflow of SEK 8,009 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase w as primarily due to investments (i) in portfolio receivables of SEK 7,038 million and SEK 5,111 million in the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively, and (ii) in the Italian joint ventures of SEK 433 million and in the Greek joint ventures of SEK 569 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to SEK 0 million and SEK 0 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, partially offset by the cash distributed by the joint ventures the Group invested in, of SEK 252 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to SEK 338 million in in the year ended December 31, 2020. Our cash flow used in investing activities decreased significantly by SEK 6,203 million, or 53%, from an outflow of SEK 11,646 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, to an outflow of SEK 5,443 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The decrease w as primarily due to (i) investments in portfolio receivables of SEK 5,135 million and SEK 7,323 million in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, and to (ii) acquisition of subsidiaries in Spain and Greece for SEK 5,135 million in 2019, w ithout a comparable outflow in 2020. _Cash flow from/(used in) financing activities_ Our cash flow used in financing activities decreased by SEK 187 million, or 43%, from SEK 432 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to an outflow of SEK 245 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The decrease w as primarily due to the decrease in borrow ings and repayment of loans of SEK 586 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 compared to SEK 1,246 million during the same period in 2021, partially offset by higher dividends to shareholders of SEK 1,632 million in the first nine months of 2022 compared to SEK 1,451 million in the first nine months of 2021. Our cash flow from financing activities w as an inflow of SEK 401 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to cash flow used in financing activities of SEK 2,569 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The cash flow in 2021 w as primarily due to the net cash from loans and borrow ings of SEK 2,139 million partially offset by the cash outflow for share repurchases of SEK 41 million, and for the payment of dividends of SEK 1,451 million, The cash used in financing activities in 2020 w as primarily due to share repurchases of SEK 1,307 million and the payment of dividends of SEK 1,332 million. 89 ----- Our cash flow used in financing activities w as SEK 2,779 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to cash flow from financing activities of SEK 5,839 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. The change w as primarily due to higher cash inflow in 2019 from loans and borrow ings for SEK 7,229 million, mainly used to finance the acquisition of subsidiaries in Spain and Greece, partially offset by the payment of dividends of SEK 1,247 million.

Subsubsection Title: Off balance sheet arrangements
Subsubsection Text: We report pledged assets consisting of deposits (primarily w ith landlords) and restricted bank balances that can be claimed by clients, suppliers or authorities in the event that w e are not to meet our contractual obligations and contingent liabilities consisting of payment guarantees. We offer payment guarantee services w hereby, against payment, w e guarantee a client's receivables from their customers. The service requires that we incur a risk of having to pay clients for the guaranteed amount in the event that the customer receivables invoices are not paid on time. In those cases w here the guarantee comes into play, w e assume the client's claim against its customer and oversee the claims case w ithin the Portfolio Investments segment. For details, see note 28 to the Financial Statements included elsew here in this Offering Memorandum. Certain of our existing joint ventures and co-investment vehicles have indebtedness w hich is only reflected on our balance sheet to the extent of our proportionate interest in the net assets of such entity as shares and participation in joint ventures. Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and qualitative disclosures about financial risk management
Subsubsection Title: M arket risk
Subsubsection Text: _Market and regulatory environment_ Our primary market risk is related to general macroeconomic conditions and local rules and statutory regulations in each of the geographical markets in w hich w e operate and w hich also impacts our clients' ability and w illingness to sell portfolios of loans and receivables, our clients' customers' ability to pay their debts as w ell as potential commission from third party collection. See "Risk Factors" for a discussion of these and other factors. _Foreign exchange risk_ We operate internationally and are exposed to foreign exchange risk arising from various currency exposures, primarily w ith respect to the Euro, NOK, Hungarian Forint and Sw iss Franc, in relation to our reporting currency Sw edish kronor. Foreign exchange risk arises from recognized assets and liabilities, net investments in foreign operations and any future commercial transactions involving foreign exchange. Exchange rate risk can be divided into transaction exposure and translation exposure. We have investments in foreign operations and the associated net assets are exposed to foreign currency translation risk. Our strategy is to manage and limit exchange rate risk through forw ard exchange contracts and currency interest rate sw aps. For further information on foreign exchange risk see Notes 1 and 34 in the Issuer's audited financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 and notes 1 and 34 in the Issuer's audited financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 included elsew here in this Offering Memorandum. To an extent, w e manage currency exposure arising from the net assets of our foreign operations through external loans in foreign currency and derivatives. - Transaction Exposure: revenue and operating expenses derived from national operations are primarily denominated in local currencies and thus currency fluctuations have only a limited impact on our operating earnings in local currency. Revenue and expenses from national operations are thus hedged in a natural w ay, w hich limits transaction exposure. Our international debt collection and debt purchasing options, how ever, are exposed to currency risk. In addition, our existing indebtedness is primarily denominated in euro and SEK, and the amounts incurred in euro and SEK do not necessarily match the cash flow s generated from operations in such currencies. - Translation Exposure: w e have operations in 25 countries. Our results of operations and financial position is reported in the relevant foreign currencies and later translated into SEK for inclusion our financial statements. In the years ended December 31, 2021, 2020 and 2019, 95%, 94% and 94%, respectively, of our revenue w as generated in a currency other than SEK. In the nine months ended September 30, 2022, 97% of our revenue w as generated in a currency other than SEK. Consequently, fluctuations in SEK exchange rates against these currencies impact our total revenue and earnings, equity and other line items in our financial statements. Our total revenue is distributed by currency as follow s, expressed in millions of SEK equivalent.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Liquidity risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that w e w ill need to incur higher than expected costs in order to fulfill our short and long-term payment obligations to external parties. This risk has historically been met through borrow ings under the Revolving Credit Facility, debt capital market transactions and bilateral loan agreements and w e expect to continue to access these sources for these purposes in the future.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Interest rate risk
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate risk is the risk of negative impacts on interest income and expenses due to movements in interest rates. Our interest rate risk relates primarily to the cost of interest-bearing debt (subject to early payment penalties). The interest rates on our debt are tied to the market rate including, in some cases, to floating rate benchmarks. Our strong cash flow generating business provides us w ith the option to repay debt or invest in portfolios, allow ing us some flexibility to manage the size and interest expense associated w ith outstanding debt and consequently our total interest cost. To establish an appropriate matching of currencies in the balance sheet and thus manage the currency risk betw een assets and liabilities, w e use currency interest rate sw aps in w hich the liabilities in SEK against NOK are sw apped at the same rate on both the start and maturity dates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Credit risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk that our counterparties are unable to fulfill their obligations to us. Each of our local entities is responsible for managing and analyzing the credit risk of each new client before standard payment and delivery terms and conditions are offered. Credit risk arises from assets, such as cash and cash equivalents, guarantees and derivative financial instruments and deposits w ith banks and financial institutions, as w ell as outstanding receivables, portfolio investments and outlays on behalf of clients. For financial assets ow ned by us, very limited collateral or other credit reinforcements have been received. Therefore, the maximum credit exposure for each class of financial assets corresponds to the carrying amount. There is also a limited risk of loss linked to our debt collection services, how ever, this risk is primarily carried by our clients. To minimize the risks related to purchase of portfolios, caution is exercised in purchase decisions. Purchases are usually made from clients w ith w hom w e have maintained long-term relationships and therefore have a thorough understanding of the receivables in question. Portfolio investments are usually purchased at prices significantly below the nominal value of the receivables and is not collateralized. Other than in the case of coinvestments, w e retain the full amounts of our collections on portfolio investments, including interest and fees. For more information on our portfolio investments, see "—Significant factors affecting results of operations—Making _portfolio investments at the right price" and "—Significant factors affecting results of operations—Gross collection_ levels—gross collection levels on portfolio investments_ " "Risk Factors—Risks related to our industry and _business—The COVID-19 pandemic, or other similar outbreaks, may adversely affect our business and exacerbate other risks discussed in this "Risk Factors" section" and "Risk Factors—Risks related to our industry and business— We may not be able to procure sufficient funding at favorable terms to purchase further portfolios as they become available."_
